title: The Best & Worst TRICEPS Exercises (Ranked Using Science)

S-Tier.setup_notes: Position the cable at a low setting and use a bar attachment. Stand facing away from the cable machine with arms overhead.
S-Tier.execution_notes: Bend and extend the elbows while keeping the arms overhead. Ensure the cable provides tension throughout the range of motion.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Provides high tension in the stretched position, feels good, and allows for simple progression. Validated by a 2023 study showing 40% more triceps growth than press downs.
S-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Long head, due to the overhead position providing a deep stretch.
S-Tier.alternative_options: Using a rope instead of a bar limits overload potential but still effective.
S-Tier.scientific_insights: 2023 study found overhead extensions caused about 40% more triceps growth than press downs.

S-Tier.setup_notes: Use an EZ bar or straight bar. Lie on a bench with the bar overhead.
S-Tier.execution_notes: Lower the bar behind the head to increase stretch, then extend the elbows to lift the bar back up.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: High tension in stretched position, feels good with EZ bar, and allows for simple progression.
S-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Long head, due to the stretch when lowering the bar behind the head.
S-Tier.alternative_options: Dumbbell Skull Crushers train each arm individually but may feel more awkward.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Attach a straight bar to a high pulley.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Stand facing the machine, grip the bar, and press down while keeping elbows close to the body.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Stable movement, even tension throughout, easy to overload, but lacks stretch at the top.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Medial and lateral heads, due to the pressing motion.
A-Tier.limitations: Does not stretch the triceps at the top.
A-Tier.alternative_options: Rope press down offers less stability and overload potential.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Position the cable at a low setting and use a rope attachment.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Stand facing away from the cable machine with arms overhead, using a rope.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Provides high tension in the stretched position, but rope limits overload potential.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Long head, due to the overhead position providing a deep stretch.
A-Tier.alternative_options: Bar attachment preferred for better overload.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Cross arms overhead and grab opposite side's cable.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Start with cables at waist height, cross arms, and extend elbows.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Hits both arms individually, addresses imbalances, but requires more setup.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Long head, due to the overhead position.
A-Tier.limitations: Requires more setup and has a learning curve.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Use a single dumbbell, seated position preferred.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Extend one arm overhead, bending and extending the elbow.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Allows for comfortable elbow positioning, less bulky than two-arm version.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Long head, due to the overhead position.
A-Tier.limitations: Less smooth tension compared to cables.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Good option if only dumbbells are available.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Use a Smith machine, set the bar at chin level.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Lower the bar to the chin area, then press back up.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Fixed path allows focus on triceps, less shoulder involvement.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Medial and lateral heads, due to pressing motion.
A-Tier.alternative_options: Barbell JM Press may cause elbow discomfort.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Use a cable machine with a low pulley.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Stand with the cable behind you, extend the arm back.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Provides even tension, good contraction, especially for long head.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Long head, due to arm position behind the torso.
A-Tier.alternative_options: Dumbbell version less effective due to tension curve.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Focus on higher reps for strong contraction.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Use a barbell, grip slightly narrower than shoulder-width.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Lower the bar to the chest, press back up.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Great for overload, consistent tension, but long head not fully engaged.
A-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Medial and lateral heads, due to pressing motion.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Attach a rope to a high pulley.
B-Tier.execution_notes: Stand facing the machine, grip the rope, and press down while flaring the wrists outward.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Feels good, but less stable and less overload potential compared to bar.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Medial and lateral heads, due to pressing motion.
B-Tier.alternative_options: Bar press down offers more stability and overload.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Use a dumbbell, seated position preferred.
B-Tier.execution_notes: Extend both arms overhead, bending and extending the elbows.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Stretches long head, but circular resistance path and bulky dumbbells can be limiting.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Long head, due to overhead position.
B-Tier.alternative_options: One arm version solves some issues.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Use a barbell, lower to chin area.
B-Tier.execution_notes: Lower the bar to the chin area, then press back up.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Solid lift, but can cause elbow discomfort and less stretch for long head.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Medial and lateral heads, due to pressing motion.
B-Tier.limitations: Elbow discomfort, less stretch for long head.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Use a dip machine, adjust seat and handles.
B-Tier.execution_notes: Press down with arms, keeping elbows close to the body.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Stable, allows focus on triceps, but pecs and delts can take over.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Medial and lateral heads, due to pressing motion.
B-Tier.limitations: Pecs and delts can take over.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Place hands close together in a diamond shape.
B-Tier.execution_notes: Lower the body to the ground, then press back up.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Harder than regular push-ups, good triceps engagement.
B-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Medial and lateral heads, due to pressing motion.
B-Tier.limitations: Not as good for overload as close grip bench press.

C-Tier.setup_notes: Attach a bar to a high pulley, use an underhand grip.
C-Tier.execution_notes: Stand facing the machine, grip the bar underhand, and press down.
C-Tier.tier_reasons: Limits strength output, grip can be a limiting factor.
C-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Medial and lateral heads, due to pressing motion.
C-Tier.limitations: Grip can be a limiting factor.
C-Tier.alternative_options: Bar press down is more effective.

C-Tier.setup_notes: Use a bench, place hands on the edge.
C-Tier.execution_notes: Lower the body by bending the elbows, then press back up.
C-Tier.tier_reasons: Good triceps engagement, but hard to overload.
C-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Medial and lateral heads, due to pressing motion.

C-Tier.setup_notes: Use a dumbbell, bend forward slightly.
C-Tier.execution_notes: Extend the arm back, keeping the elbow close to the body.
C-Tier.tier_reasons: Zero tension at stretch, tension increases as muscle contracts.
C-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Long head, due to arm position behind the torso.

C-Tier.setup_notes: Place hands close together under the chest.
C-Tier.execution_notes: Lower the body to the ground, then press back up.
C-Tier.tier_reasons: Hard to overload beyond beginner stage.
C-Tier.targeted_muscle_parts: Medial and lateral heads, due to pressing motion.

muscle_group: Triceps (lateral head, medial head, long head)
criterias: The exercise must provide significant tension, especially when the muscle is stretched.
The exercise should not cause pain and should have a smooth resistance profile.
The exercise should allow for easy addition of weight or reps over time.
muscle_part_anatomy_function: Gives the triceps a rounded shape.
Runs down the middle, adding shape to the arm.
Beefs up the triceps from the rear and performs shoulder extension.
main_knowledge_summary.form_details: Press downs can be done using a rope, bar, or reverse grip. The rope allows for a harder contraction by driving handles apart but is less stable. The bar provides more stability and even tension. Overhead cable extensions put the long head under a bigger stretch. Skull crushers should arc the bar back behind the head for better tension. JM press is a hybrid between a close grip bench press and a skull crusher. Kickbacks should focus on a strong contraction with the arm held back.
main_knowledge_summary.research_insights: A 2023 study found that overhead extensions caused about 40% more triceps growth than press downs, highlighting the importance of stretching the long head for muscle growth.
main_knowledge_summary.optimization_notes: For optimal triceps development, include exercises that target the long head in a stretched position, such as overhead extensions. Use a variety of shoulder angles to ensure proportional development. Consider exercises like cable kickbacks for a full squeeze of the long head. Progress by adding weight or reps weekly.
